segments.text: In late 1987 and in 1988, there was a great deal of excitement in the House of South Texas area about the expansion of higher education in South Texas and the further development of
this area with regards to institutions of higher education.
There was no question that South Texas had been neglected with regards to higher education.
And the legislators in South Texas placed the blame at the feet of the legislature as a whole.
The truth of the matter is that the legislature responds to requests that are made by individual legislators.
Not that they always get what they ask for, but they first have to ask for it.
Now Texas, by 1987, had emerged from the old patrone system that really had little regard for higher education for its masses.
and most of the legislators responded accordingly.

I recall one time in earlier years when I was serving in the legislature, this was about 1974 as I can best remember, I struck up a conversation with the state representative from Duval County one day and
I stated that I see that he has an opponent in the election.
And he was devoting some time to campaigning.
Let me know very quickly that he did not have to campaign, that George Parr elected him, and see to it that he was reelected.
This particular state representative at that time had I'm sure no interest in promoting higher education in South Texas.
In 87 and 88 all of this had changed with the election of a
new generation of legislators that were no longer under the control of certain politically powerful individuals.
This is not to suggest that all state representatives and senators in South Texas were under anyone's person's control, such as George Parr,
is simply to point out that there was that environment in South Texas in the earlier years and prior years.
We began to think about what we would be proposing to the joint committee that was established to look at higher education in South Texas.
We came to certain conclusions, but recognized the fact that the University of Texas system would need to be conferred with on all these matters.
There were essentially five institutions, three that existed within the University of South Texas system.
i.e., Corpus Christi State University, Texas A&I University in Kingsville, and Laredo State University in Laredo.
In Edinburgh, Texas, there was Pan American University with a branch in Brownsville.
that was strictly an upper-level institution and located on the Junior College campus in Brownsville, Texas.
Our initial meeting with the University of Texas System Chancellor

that they were interested in Pan American University at Edinburgh with its branch in Brownsville and Laredo State University becoming a part of the University of Texas system and leaving the Texas A&M University system with Corpus Christi State University and Texas A&I University.

in Laredo State University was because of the fact they had University of Texas at El Paso on the border to the west and would have Pan American University in Brownsville campus to the east and would like to have Laredo since it was also located on the border.

There was a great deal of interest in international trade with Mexico at the time and the University of Texas System Chancellor felt like that they, being the University of Texas System, would like to take the lead in international trade and therefore would like to have Laredo State University in their system.
impression was that this would be the final result for several reasons.
Number one, Pan American University had almost become a part of the University of Texas system some years earlier and there had always been that close tie.
Number two, the state senator in the Lareda area was a graduate of the University of Texas system
and would probably lean toward putting Laredo in the University of Texas system.
The A&I University was a logical fit with Texas A&M University because of the programs that they offered.
And the Texas system chancellor had let the people in Corpus Christi know that they were not interested in Corpus Christi.
I failed to take into account was the fact that the University of Texas system had two other upper level institutions within its system already.
One at Tyler and the University of Texas at Permian Basin.
The state was an upper level institution as well as Corpus Christi State University.
It was not long until we were notified that the University of Texas system had no interest in Laredo State University becoming a part of their system.
The reason
became quite obvious that they did not want to take in any upper-level institutions that were interested in becoming four-year institutions.
It's quite evident that both Corpus Christi State University and Laredo State University wanted four-year status.

left the Texas A&M University system with the old South Texas system intact, i.e., Corpus Christi State University, Texas A&I, and Laredo, with the University of Texas system picking up Pan American University and its branch in Brownsville.
For the misunderstandings in the merger talk,
was the Chamber of Commerce people thinking that if they joined the University of Texas system or the Texas A&M University system, they would become heirs of the permanent university fund.
They just had not read the Texas Constitution, which clearly would leave these institutions outside of the Permanent University Fund and continue in the Higher Education Assistance Fund.
Hearings were held during this interim period in Brownsville, Edinburgh, and Laredo.
I recall that the University of Texas system chancellor and I traveled together attending those hearings and testifying before the joint committee.
In those hearings that the University of Texas system chancellor made it clear that they could not support an institution moving from an upper level status to four year status.
On the other hand, I was authorized by the NM System Board of Regents to say that we would support such a move if the legislature so designated.
Later on, I will discuss the name change controversy with regards to the South Texas Institution's
merger into the Texas A&M University System and the Lieutenant Governor's later interest in moving the Laredo State University to the University of Texas System.
As we moved into the legislative session convening in January of 1989,
was evident to me that we were going to have a struggle with regards to the general revenue appropriations to higher education.
Representative Tom Uher, who had been a champion for higher education, had been removed from his position as chairman of the Budget and Oversight Committee in the House Committee on Higher Education.
the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee had instructed all proposals to contain a 5% reduction in general revenue appropriations.

The chairman of the Budget and Oversight Committee that sat on the Higher Education Committee and the Appropriations Committee began to make the 5% reductions, but the cuts were even deeper than that because he was adding special items for members that served on his committee.
A school was not on the committee.
they resulted, the school got even bigger cuts than 5%.
Though Representative Uher had been removed from the subcommittee that made the proposal to the Higher Education Committee and then on to the
Appropriations Committee, he still was a member of the Higher Education Committee.
He approached me and the rest of higher education with a proposal that we fund higher education with a $500 million increase that would be fairly and evenly spread throughout higher education.
The University of Texas system had created a model for doing this, and so it was suggested that they would furnish the dollar amounts to Representative Uher.
We're working on a very short time fuse, but University of Texas system officials felt like that they could accomplish this in very short order.
We had less than one week to get all this done.
After a few days had passed, I decided to do a follow-up to be sure that the University of Texas system was putting together a proposal that Representative Uher had requested.
Learned that they planned to do nothing about it, even though they had said they would.
Learning this, I asked our officials here at the Texas A&M University System if they could put together such a proposal within a matter of hours.
We were able to do this and carry it to Representative Uher and to all of higher education the following week.
Representative Uher offered his substitute to the full Committee on Higher Education, and it passed.

However, when the proposal reached the House Appropriations Committee, Chairman Rudd refused to accept it because it was over the 5% reduction that, in fact, had an increase that he had said that he wanted in
the proposal that came forward.
Interesting to note, however, that within a few days following this proposal being presented to the House Appropriations Committee
The committee chairman and the speaker reversed their positions and decided that these reductions would not be in order and that they would no longer be imposed by the chairman.
The 1989 General Appropriations Act did in fact
include about four to five hundred million dollars additional funds for higher education, almost identical in dollar amounts to those that Representative Uher had proposed.
The bill to transfer the

South Texas institutions into the Texas A&M University system and the University of Texas system that has been previously discussed was filed as two separate bills and were passed through the legislature with relative ease.
One of the issues that was in the
bill to transfer the South Texas University system into the Texas A&M University system dealt with the changing of the names of those institutions.
Regents at that time objected to the dealing with the name changes in the bill and asked me to discuss it with the author of the bill.
They did this and the author agreed to withdraw the provision in the bill that provided for name changes of the South Texas institutions.
There was a separate bill passed that gave the A&M System Board of Regents the authority to make these name changes.
A&M Board took no action on this matter for quite some time, which led to infuriating the senators in the South Texas system and the lieutenant governor at a later date.
I will discuss when we get to
There were other bills in 1989 that were significant to the Texas A&M University System.
One that specifically mentioned Texas A&M or the Texas A&M University System was a bill to publish a Central Texas College
in Killeen and a private college on the Central Texas College campus and create a four-year institution in Killeen near Fort Hood known as Central Texas University.
The bill was passed by Representative Stan Sleater
with the understanding that he would be later interested in making it a part of the A&M system but did not want to deal with that issue at this time.
The bill had a future date of 1999 that the new university would be created, provided
certain obligations were taken care of and the two existing boards were abolished, creating a new board for a state-supported institution.
One of the concessions that Representative Sleater had to make to get the bill passed and signed, or not passed, but signed by the governor, Ann Richards, was to
agreed to pass a bill in a special session that would follow to allow the Coordinating Board to approve this new institution before it became in effect.
Representative Sleater did subsequently pass such a bill which required the Coordinating Board's approval of
the new institution prior to it coming into existence.
This is still a pending matter and has not been resolved by the Coordinating Board at this time that I am at this time of this being written.
The 1989 regular session was a session that the student recreation sports fee was established for Texas A&M University.
This generated the funds and the bonding allowance, bonding authority for the building of the
student recreation center that is now one of the magnificent facilities on the Texas A&M campus.

There was concern on the part of the local legislator that the students might not want to assess themselves for the fee to build the facility since they would never get to use it by the time it was built.
And this was really something that the administration wanted.
But we were able to convince the legislature that the students really and truly did want it and were willing to pay for it.
Issues in the appropriations process was the threat of losing accreditation of the vet school.
The veterinary school at Texas A&M had been threatened with loss of accreditation if they did not improve their facilities.

This may have not been as serious a threat as it first appeared, but was used as leverage to get appropriations for the vet school and to bring the board around to appropriating the funds to build additional facilities at the vet school.
The discussion and hearing regarding the accreditation of the vet school led to a rider that required whatever tuition the vet school raised to be spent on the programs at that particular school.
This removed some of the flexibility that had previously been
given Texas A&M in expending their tuition revenue monies that were not designated for any particular college or school within the Texas A&M.
After 1989, the Texas A&M University System Board of Regents had decided to develop and build the facilities for an Institute of Biosciences and Technology
on the side of the old Shamrock Hotel building in Houston, Texas, which is across the street and on Main Street from the Texas Medical Center.
Funds were generated from primarily federal sources and some private sources to get the buildings built.
U.S.
Senator Lloyd Benson was chiefly responsible in getting these funds in the appropriations bills over the years at the federal level.
before the 1989 Texas legislature was the need for funding the facility for operational expenses once it was open.
This was to be primarily a research or solely a research facility to work with the Texas Medical Center.
and would give the Texas Medical Center access to the expertise on the main campus at Texas A&M University.
The Texas A&M System Board of Regents had the authority to establish the institute without legislative approval, but it had been my experience that if the legislature acted
affirmatively on such a program, there was a better chance of getting appropriation.
So we decided to
and asked the legislature to officially sanction the program by a bill that would establish the Institute of Biosciences and Technology in Houston as a part of Texas A&M University.
I think this did, in fact, get us a $7.5 million appropriation
for that biennium, for the upcoming biennium beginning in 1989 for the Institute.
Without the accompanying bill, we very likely would not have gotten funding for the Institute.
Very similar program,
was one in Galveston at Texas A&M University, Galveston, called the Texas Institute of Oceanography.
The Texas Institute of Oceanography, as the Institute of Bioscience and Technology, could be approved and established by the Texas A&M University System Board of Regents.
But here again, the question was a matter of funding.
So a bill was filed to create, by legislative act, the Texas Institute of Oceanography in Galveston in hopes that we could get an appropriations attached to that or to accompany that creation.
Again, this was...
done very similar to the Institute of Biosciences and Technology, and a $1.3 million appropriation was attached.
Incidentally, the Texas Institute of Oceanography is created and allows A&M to work with the University of Texas in its research programs.
I'm not sure whether that has ever happened.
been accomplished or not, but it is a part of the legislation.
The Texas A&M University system was fortunate in 1989 to have the appointment of its own local state senator from Bryan College Station appointed as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
This came about as a result of the defeat of the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee in his local district, Senator Grant Jones.
Later than the appointment of Caperton, most of the leadership in the legislature remained about the same as it was in 1987.

During the elections in 1990, Senator Caperton of Bryan chose not to seek re-election and convening of the legislative session in 1991, Senator John Monford was named chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
Chairman Monford was appointed by Lieutenant Governor Bob Bullock.
The leadership in the House remained the same.
Gibb Lewis was Speaker and Jim Rudd remained as Chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.

The 1991 regular session of the Texas Legislature would be the first session that the three South Texas schools, Corpus Christi State University, Laredo State University, and Texas A&I would function as a part of the Texas A&M University system.
One of the major concerns of Corpus Christi State University and Laredo State University was the problem of how to construct facilities on those campuses and where the monies could come from.

I had suggested to the president of Corpus Christi State University when the question arose that years before, tuition revenue bonds had been authorized by the legislature and might be a possible source of funds for the building of facilities on that campus.

Tuition revenue bonds sound like a great idea at first until you realize that it's really money, if they're really general revenue bonds, you're taking the money directly out of the general revenue to replace the tuition revenue that is used to retire those bonds.
Otherwise, the institution would suffer a great loss of revenue
that it needs for its operations.
A bill was drafted authorizing Corpus Christi State University to sell bonds, pledging tuition revenue from throughout the Texas A&M University system, and the bill was passed and became law.

Earlier that same year, there was a special session, and Laredo State University, having a similar problem, decided to copy the bill that Corpus Christi State University had passed authorizing the sale of bonds pledging tuition revenue of the Texas A&M University system.

The radar state was able to get a bill through in that special session, and so they were likewise authorized to pledge tuition revenue of the A&M system to sell bonds to raise funds for capital improvements.
It was about this time that I decided to once again try to develop a grassroots program for the Texas A&M University System.
This later became known as TAMUS LIFE, which is an acronym for the Texas A&M University System Legislative Information for Education.
New programs have been developed
around the country, but they were springing up because of the lack of support for higher education, and most of this was because of the economic times that we were going through.
I began to review what other states were doing and found out that most of these successful programs were being operated by the alumni associations in various states.
There were some states like Indiana where several universities had gone together to create one statewide organization.
The Texas A&M University system was a system consisting of a number of institutions.
I knew that the alumni connection would not work as a way to spin off a grassroots organization.
The only model for a system operating such a program was California.
It appeared to have a very successful program that operated at the system level.
The more I learned about grassroots organizations in other states, the more encouraged I became that Texas A&M University System needed a similar program.
So hopeful that we could link up with the University of Texas System, but this never occurred.
I did run across two studies where legislators and former legislators were surveyed,
to determine what influenced them with regards to their decisions on higher education.
The two states that had conducted a survey were Florida and Alabama.
The results of the two are very similar, and I will not go into detail with regards to those results of those studies.
However, to summarize, they both agreed that their own lifetime experiences, speaking now of legislators,
was the greatest influencing factor.
There's nothing that a grassroots organization can do to change or influence the lifetime experiences that a legislator has had with regards to higher education.
Moving on to the second most important influencing factor was a trusted friend.
areas where a grassroots organization can have a tremendous impact by identifying those trusted friends and asking them to assist whenever the need arises.
It's interesting to note that at the very bottom of the scale were such factors as radio ads, TV ads, newspapers, and billboards.
These were at the bottom of the
list of priorities as far as legislators are concerned in influencing factors.
Our effort with Tempest Live was to set out to identify friends of legislators that would speak favorably for higher education and the A&M system schools.
There were several deterrents to this being as successful a program as it could be.
For one, the newer schools that had come in saw Texas A&M University as the enemy because they were not allowing the other schools to share in the permanent university fund.
Of course, this is something A&M had no control over since it is a part of the Texas Constitution.

Second, we found that the schools were very proprietary in sharing with the system a list of their friends that they had established themselves and did not want to share their support groups with the system.
The A&M system as an entity has no alumni,
It had to draw upon the various alumni from the various institutions.
A program of this sort to be successful requires that the people that are supporting you, are forming the support group, must be informed on the issues and how they should contact their legislators.

To accomplish this, we went around the state, mainly in areas where we had colleges and universities that are part of the Texas A&M University System, and met with the support groups and explained to them what they could do and how they could be of assistance to us.
I detected that we were only getting token support
from the leadership on the various campuses.
By the session beginning in 1993, we did have a core group of about 800 supporters that were signed up.
And we were able to make some effective use of this in contacting legislators and letting them know of these people supporting higher education and Texas A&M University System in particular.

In one particular case, very late in the regular session of 1993, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee called several of us to his office, and several of us being some of the people in Austin that worked with higher education institutions, and indicated to us that it was very important that the public school finance bill pass in the House.
Otherwise, the appropriations bill would have to be reopened and monies diverted from higher education to the public school finance bill.
This was a direct threat to higher education appropriations, which had been pretty well buttoned down by then.
So I immediately contacted our statewide chairman,

of our grassroots program and he went out of communications to the leaders of the Tammis Life program asking them to contact their house members and assist in getting the public school finance bill passed.
I always hope that
the people in the support group understand why it's necessary to support something like public school finance at such a time without saying that you had been threatened.
But it was effective and we were able to let the leadership know that in the legislature
was that we had taken such action and I'm sure that it was a very critical issue to them and I'm sure they appreciated our support.
Getting public school finance passed during the regular session.
There was one other piece of legislation that was introduced by a legislator from Lubbock that would have
dismantle the permanent university fund.
I did not see this as an immediate threat to the permanent university fund because of the interrelationships and the fact that the legislator was a first term member and just had not
recognized how much support could be generated for the permanent university fund if it became necessary.
I did expect him to get a hearing on his bill because the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee was a graduate and a strong supporter of Texas Tech.
I suggested to our people that we not get too exercised over the bill at its initial stages, but the University of Texas system took a different approach.
They were very active in trying to get the bill killed very early.

This led to them being lectured to by the Chairman's House Appropriations Committee that they had violated a provision in the appropriations bill which prohibits that work for an institution or state agency from lobbying for or against legislation.
It is a very fine line, but there is a difference in going to someone and asking him to vote against the bill and going to him and explaining the impact of the legislation.
On the very last day of that legislation, I was informed that I was no longer Executive Secretary of the Board of Regents and was being reassigned as Director of Public Policy.
This was described to me as a lateral move, but obviously it was not.
The position of director is not as elevated as the position of vice chancellor.
I was never advised as to why this change was made.
And it would serve no useful purpose for me to speculate as to why the position change was made and why the position of Director of Public Policy was even created.
It was very difficult and trying because for one thing, we were changing chancellors about every year.
There were 12 months during that period of time.

In the summer of 1994, approximately one year later, the chancellor was reassigned, and at that time, the system vice chancellor and general counsel was moved to Austin and reassigned as vice chancellor for state affairs.
Shortly thereafter, I started spending two days in Austin
when during the interim when the legislature was not in session to be in touch with the new vice chancellor for state affairs and to have secretarial support.
By the time the legislature convened in January 1995 another new chancellor had been named and
A new person was brought in to serve as chief for legislative affairs.
This was an unfilled position that had been on the books for some time.
In the 1995 legislative session, I spent as much time in Austin as I had in the past.
That is three or four days a week during the time they're in session.
And even more than that, toward the end of the session,
able to accomplish a great deal during that session, just being the eyes and ears of the system.
Members of the legislature continued to call upon me and seek my advice on various issues.
At one point in time during the session, the chairman of the, the dean of the Senate,
called me in to work on legislation that would create a medical branch in Corpus Christi, part of the Texas A&M University Medical School.
The legislation did not get very far through the process, but I was able to provide a supportive role to this influential member of the Texas Senate.

In the 1993 regular session of the Texas legislature, a bill was filed that would transfer Texas A&M International University in Laredo from the Texas A&M University system to the University of Texas system.
This was not in the best interest of the Texas A&M University system and would have created a negative image on the part of
Texas A&M University and the Texas A&M University system.
It passed easily in the Texas Senate with the support of the Lieutenant Governor and to the House of Representatives was referred to the House Higher Education Committee for a hearing.
